No forms either
I’m back to being obsessed with improving my core web vitals.  I’m so close, but so far away.

Do note, core web vitals is still only one of thousands of ranking factors that Google looks at.

Danny Sullivan at Google:
> _“First of all, it remains one of many things._
> _Secondly, it’s always the case that we’re going to try to return the best content based on this basket or bucket of things._
> _So, maybe you don’t have the best page experience… But if you’re still the most relevant content, that is going to you know overall on various things we’re looking at._
> _I think it’s not a case of start being all super concerned. And understand that we want to make sure that this is coming in a moderated fashion…_
> _But over time what will happen is, as more and more content is coming up in page experience and if you’re in a situation where things are all relatively equal, the things that are more page experience and oriented are likely to start doing better._
> _So it’s not… I don’t think freak out but do pay attention to it, do understand that it’s a new thing that you need to keep in mind._
> _That’s why we’re highlighting it.”_

With web page performance you are always going to have to make trade offs.

For example if all you cared about was speed, you’d be delivering web safe fonts on a white background HTML only  web page with minimal images. No JavaScript and minimal CSS.

For most businesses there’s value in branding. There’s value in analyzing your marketing strategies because it in turn results in higher sales.

If you have a form on your site that is accounting for 50+% of your sales/leads. Are you going to cut that form out just to improve page speed? No that’d be ridiculous.

Focus on what makes your flywheel spin. Site speed is one of thousands of factors that affect customers experience with your company.

Focus on reducing friction for yourself and consider comparing to competitors to see how things will really shake out overall.

If your page speed is on average better than your competitor, it’s probably more valuable to focus on other aspects of your flywheel, because you’re not likely to see a drastic difference in the core web vitals update.
Yes good positioning Jon.

While we're on this fun thread though I do have one other question... When I run PageSpeed Insights I can see massive swings in page score (sometimes 30+ points) without any changes in code/content. I assume this is due to network conditions and the initial server response time but I'm wondering if others have experienced similar and if there are any patterns.

Yes generally speaking it’s a result of the network connection. There’s a lot of different factors at play. Basically the score is calculated by a weighted percentage of actual measurements on the page, and not any of the recommendations google puts out at the bottom of the report.

So things like your own computer’s cpu usage, memory, cpu speed, gpu speed(if the page utilizes gpu), your network conditions, browser extensions, the network conditions of all of the nodes between you and the server, etc, all of that have an affect on the measurements. Most of it is usually minimal but it does fluctuate.

Additionally the lighthouse API and google page speed insights frequently return differing results.

In other words, you could follow every one of Google’s recommendations, but your router, or ISP could have a little hiccup in the chain and boom your score tanks for no good reason.

This is why you should look at multiple tools, and look at lab data vs real world data

We have a little more context into this here:
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/guides/speed#performance-testing>

Agreed with Jon.  The reality of using the lighthouse API means that I can swing my numbers quite a bit.  Opening in an incognito window on the fastest network I have access to vs regular browsing can mean the difference between passing or failing core vitals

But where I cant find parameter where I get whole email content. Can anyone help me here?

You should not do a call out from your front end to HubSpot Apis using your hapikey as this would expose your key on your website

Hi all, this may not be the best thread and has maybe been answered already, in that case, if someone could link to the thread that'd be amazing. I'm working on a hero section for a client and currently we just have a dnd section with a background image, but they would like the option to also put a gif in the form of a video tag with an mp4. Is there a way I can add some sort of functionality that will let them choose whether they'd like an image or video so that I can achieve this? I want the video to span the width of the page as the background image (cover) does.

It unfortunately completely depends Chris. for example if you use the API, it’s Googles servers doing all the testing - but it seems to be different servers than Google Page Speed. If you use google page speed insights it’s google’s servers doing the testing. If you use lighthouse in your browser it’s all done locally on your computer.

Regardless even with Google Page Speed and the API those measurements will still be different every time for the same exact reasons, it’s just a different computer doing the test.

For a more full picture of your site’s performance you should really look at multiple tools, both lab and real world and consider even running tests multiple times and averaging the results.
is there an efficient way to create a template from a page that has been modified/created/edited in the website editor?
For example, someone uses a simple page template and adds new content, modules, etc.
and then I want to create a new "selectable" template from that page

The other thing that none of these tests will do which is honestly a huge deal - they don’t test at all your site’s overall performance. They are testing 1 page.

So for example, if you have one monolithic CSS file and a monolithic JS file, you wont see recommendations for “reduce http requests” but you’re being really inefficient on delivering assets. Besides the point that reducing http requests isn’t really that big of a deal in the age of HTTP2, I mean don’t go crazy and have a million separate files but thinking in terms of modules is brilliant.

Instead if you split your files. say group your CSS for your header and footer modules to be 1 require_css’d file or linked css file. You now have the performance benefit that the code that is used on every single page gets cached separately from your content modules.

By keeping your css in your content modules you gain a huge benefit. You’re only loading code that’s actually needed to render the current page. If the user ever encounters the module again, that css/js is loaded from cache. Making subsequent page loads drastically faster.

Additionally if you have monolithic css/js you have an additional problem in that any time you make an update, you are invalidating the cache for all of your CSS or JS. Meaning the browser has to refetch a large file instead of just the bytes of data that you actually updated.

So if you take that modular and grouped approach to your css/JS your subsequent page loads will be drastically faster because the browser is only fetching the data it doesn’t already have, often it’s a matter of a few kb. Making fetching it really fast.

This additionally can be a huge huge deal to someone who is on a bad cell network. I mean think about it this way. if you’ve got a spotty signal, do you want your phone to download a ton of code that’s not needed for the current page, or do you just want to download what’s needed in that moment so you can get something done?
